justification: The article states that "Prominent examples include The Eriksen-Flanker paradigm … Students work in small groups to discuss which aspects of attention can be reliably quantified using these paradigms," indicating this task is used to measure attention.

In introducing measurement of attention, the curriculum lists "the Stroop paradigm (Stroop, 1935)" as one of the "well-validated experimental paradigms used in attention research," showing Stroop is employed to assess attention.

The text names "Continuous Performance Tasks (Rosvold et al., 1956)" alongside other paradigms and notes that students examine "which aspects of attention can be reliably quantified using these paradigms," confirming CPTs serve as an attention measure.

During a live class demonstration, "we use a mobile EEG system (EMOTIV EPOC+) … their brainwaves are projected for the entire class to see," showing that the EMOTIV EPOC+ device is the instrument for recording students’ neural activity.
